bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Paul Hayes, December 10, 1953

div1.p: Hench inquires about the possibility of receiving a World War II medal which he believes everyone in the army received.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Paul Hayes, December 10, 1953
div1.opener:
December 10, 1953
Colonel Paul Hayes
Chief Medical Consultant
Department of the Army
Office of the Surgeon General
Washington 25, D.C.
My dear Colonel Hayes:
div1.p:
I think you have known of my interest and hobby - the whole story of the
conquest of yellow fever. Permit me to send you, confidentially, a copy
of the letter I have just sent to General Armstrong. I do not think you
need to do anything for me as I believe General Armstrong knows of my
interest and is quite sympathetic with it because, after all, what we
have done has, I hope, made the Cubans more sympathetic to the work of
the U. S. Army Commission. But I do want you to have the letter in
case, for any reason, General Armstrong should mention the matter to
you.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. HENCH, M.C. PSH:alc
P.S.: Can I bother you about a matter which some might consider small
and perhaps foolish. Although I never went overseas during my four
years of service in the Army and never had the opportunity even to win
a good conduct medal, I have on occasion wished that I had picked up
the medal which everyone in the Army got, I believe the medal of the
second World War, analogous to the Victory Medal of World War I. I
was demobilized hastily at the Pentagon in January 1946 and waited
around for nothing, I can assure you. Since then, I have occasionally
heard of this medal but don't even know its name and don't know how
or where to apply for it. Frankly and honestly, I would like to collect
one to leave to my kids. Would you be so good as to humor a very un-
heroic “ex-medical officer” and tell me if I am all wet on this and, if
I am not, tell me where I should apply? I retain from Army days my
allergy to making five carbon copies and perhaps when I am in Washington
in February I could simply go to some office in the Pentagon with my
discharge paper and make a simple thing of it.
If I can find them, I will bring along with me in February the snapshots
that I took of the very delightful weekend that I spent with you when
I took that consultant's trip for the Medical Corps.
